head.title: The Roads a Woman Can Take

hedline.hl1: The Roads a Woman Can Take

abstract.p: Rissa Sable Zimmerman letter reminds Maureen Dowd that there are women, New Yorkers included, who choose both to work and raise families (S)

block.p: Maureen Dowd (column, June 7) criticizes women who'd ''ditch work if they could afford to.'' Had she posed her question to the husbands of these women, I'd bet they'd opt for ditching work, too. Believe it or not, some of us (New Yorkers included) choose both to work and raise our families.

Maureen Dowd (column, June 7) criticizes women who'd ''ditch work if they could afford to.'' Had she posed her question to the husbands of these women, I'd bet they'd opt for ditching work, too. Believe it or not, some of us (New Yorkers included) choose both to work and raise our families.

There are, of course, those of us who have no choice but to work, climb that ladder and evolve professionally while facing gender bias head on. Whether we are demanding equality, having fun or desiring to loll about, we women are entitled, just as men are, to pursue what we want. The injustice lies in the restrictions we face in the course of our pursuits.
RISSA SABLE ZIMMERMAN Dix Hills, N.Y., June 7, 2000
